title: 114_s2192
content: The "NICS Reporting Improvement Act" requires states to electronically provide data to the National Instant Criminal Background Check system or face penalties. Section 102(b) of the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 requires the Attorney General to establish a plan with states and tribal governments for better reporting to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, including benchmarks and penalties for non-compliance. During the 4-year period, the Attorney General will withhold a percentage of funds allocated to states under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act if they do not meet reporting benchmarks to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. During a 4-year period, the Attorney General will withhold funds from states under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act if they fail to meet reporting benchmarks for the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The withheld amounts are 5%, 13%, and 15% for the first, second, and third years respectively. The Attorney General will withhold funds from states under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act if they fail to meet reporting benchmarks for the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. States failing to establish a plan will be treated as not meeting any benchmark. The Attorney General will publish an annual report on state compliance. The Department of Justice will assess each State's compliance with established benchmarks for the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 is amended to provide grants to states for the improvement of coordination and automation of NICS record reporting. The Attorney General will provide grants to States, Indian tribal governments, and State court systems for improving the automation and transmittal of records identifying individuals prohibited from possessing firearms. Grants can only be used for necessary assessments. The Attorney General will provide grants to States, Indian tribal governments, and State court systems for improving the automation and transmittal of records related to individuals prohibited from possessing firearms. Grants can be used for assessments, implementing policies, creating electronic systems for accurate information related to background checks. The grants provided by the Attorney General aim to assist States, Indian tribal governments, and State court systems in enhancing their capacity for background checks using the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. Eligibility for the grant requires certification that the entity is not prohibited by State law from submitting mental health records to the system. The Federal share of activities funded by grants under this section is limited to 25 percent, except for infrastructure or system development related to improving record reporting to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System, which can be fully funded. Up to 5 percent of grant funding is reserved for Indian tribal governments, and preferential consideration is given in awarding grants. In awarding grants under this section, the Attorney General shall give preferential consideration to a State or Indian tribal government that has met certain benchmarks and implemented a relief from disabilities program. $100,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2020. Section 1(b) of the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007 is amended by updating the item relating to section 103. Sec. 103. Grants to States for improvement of coordination and automation of NICS record reporting. The amendments made by this Act shall take effect 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
